contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: accúḷ is an act of producing words and alphabets by moving writing instruments. On the other hand, horúḷ focuses more on writing as a means of recording information, having the connotation of somewhat long, coherent writing.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: What accúḷ takes in the accusative is what gets created as the result of writing (ex. alphabets).

contents.title: usage
contents.text: must be followed by a noun

translations.title: postposition
forms: with (in the sense of "in the company of")

translations.title: pseudo-genitive postposition
forms: with (in the sense of "in the company of")
with (in the sense of "by means of")

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: There isn't difference between bhán and cájau when denoting "with" (in the sense of "in the company of"), though cájau tends to be preferred. "through" can only be expressed with bhán.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: This word is used for the pseudo-genitive for bhán, cájau and the instrumental case.

contents.text: Cannot be used in the sense of "by means of", for which the instrumental case is used.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: There isn't difference between bhán and cájau when denoting "with" (in the sense of "in the company of"), though cájau tends to be preferred. "through" can only be expressed with bhán.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Appended after the verb to denote that the speaker is speaking from hearsay.

translations.title: pseudo-genitive postposition
forms: （不定詞またはkoḍiを受けて）〜についての

contents.title: usage
contents.text: infinitiveまたはkoḍiが直前に来て、「〜を思う」など主に思考にまつわるverb や機能語的性質が強いverb の意味上のaccusativeを表すのが普通である。

translations.title: vowel-stem noun
forms: area (not as in "the area of a square")

contents.title: usage
contents.text: nominative nominative hemと使うとコピュラ（〜である）としてふるまい、future participle・past participleに後置することで完了表現を作る。コピュラ自身の命令形・past participleなどを作るためには、同義語の通常verb bhápúḷを用いる。

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: accúḷ is an act of producing words and alphabets by moving writing instruments. On the other hand, horúḷ focuses more on writing as a means of recording information, having the connotation of somewhat long, coherent writing.

translations.title: vowel-stem noun
forms: (modified with the genitive of a numeral and is followed by hína) times (as in once

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: While káṇám implies the notion of infinite eternity, bhákáṇa simply signifies that something always holds.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: While the noun "bhákáṇa" can only be used in the genitive case, "káṇám" can be used in all cases. Also, while "káṇám"はどちらかというと未来に無限に続くことを意図するのに対し、bhákáṇaは単に「常である」様を表す。

contents.title: usage
contents.text: For "they", that is, the plural for "he", kiṣlo is the right word to use; on the other hand, "those ones over there" or "men" is expressed by the regular plural form kízá.

contents.title: cognate(s)
contents.text:
(third person masculine singular, that one over there) 藍kisi,皇ki
(man, male) 牌ki1,藍uki,藍ki

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: lási is preferred over ásúka when denoting a single person.Note, however, that, unlike the English word "one", *lásizá cannot be used to mean two or more persons.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: In some dialects, this verb takes the accusative, not the instrumental.

translations.title: dynamic verb
forms: to use/utilize [accusative] for the purpose of [hína]

contents.title: cognate(s)
contents.text: relatively recent borrowing of 牌tak1,藍taku

contents.title: usage
contents.text: As can be seen from the Lin character, the primary meaning is the ink, not the inkstick.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: "nautu" means "word"; "zepha" denotes "language", composed of many "nautu" and grammar. "bhátán zepha" is "bhátán language"; "bhátán nautu" is "bhátán words".

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Used as the suppletive form for the non-conjugating verb "hem". Using bhápúḷ in the situation where hem suffices has the slight connotation of formality.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: From ko + (genitive suffix)-om. Must be followed by a noun.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: cánajúḷ is not generally used when a new piece of information was obtained. cánajúḷ basically is a negation of the state that "you already know it but haven't consciously thought about it".

contents.title: usage
contents.text: must be followed by a singular noun. Even though semantically plural, the noun following "bhá" should be in its singular form.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: singulare tantum noun; even when semantically plural, singular declensions are always used.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Unlike 藍t'aitaiu, which is used solely to express sadness, deja can also be used for positive situations.

translations.title: stative verb
forms: to be something due to special circumstances

contents.title: cognate(s)
contents.text: Of uncertain origin. Folk etymology relates it to "bhá aṭam" (all gods).

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Denotes series of interconnected rings; it does not have the connotation/nuance of binding/shackles/constraint.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Since this word comes from zíghúḷ "to move steadily", zíghíṣ can refer to any kind of time-measuring device that has to do with steady motion, whether it is a table clock, a wristwatch, a sundial or an hourglass.

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
to say "somewhere under A", you use A's instrumental case followed by rúṣ.
ṣoyabhau rúṣán bhoṇau "a burrow under a wall"

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
Appears only after a genitive or a prenominal. Singular nominative tends to appear as zero. Refers to things, not to persons.
ko ámaom hem? Is this yours?
ámaom kele sujamúha? Do you use yours?

translations.title: dynamic verb
forms: 〜(accusative)（という平面）を横切って進む

contents.title: usage
contents.text: 狭い道のようなものを対象としては（道に沿った方向の移動でも道を横切る方向の移動でも）使うことができない。

translations.title: stative verb
forms: for [nominative] to be able to see/observe [accusative]

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: aḍuhazoúḷは「見るために目とか顔とかを動かし、その結果として見て、見終わって顔などを戻す」みたいな一連の動作を指す。okákúḷはもっと語義が広く、意図性の有無に関わらず目から情報が入っている状態を指す。

translations.title: instantaneous verb
forms: for [nominative] to think/feel that he/she/they himself/herself/themselves want [accusative]
(and the like; basically the instantaneous versions of the same verb)

translations.title: stative verb
forms: to want (someone) to do [infinitive that has the different subject from the main clause+ema]

contents.title: usage
contents.text: It is originally the same word as "rijz" (aspiration, wish), which is formed by appending the nominalization suffix #1 to "rijúḷ". However, it is spelled differently owing to the subtle difference in the meaning.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Usually takes an infinitive or [verb + nominalization suffix #4] as the subject.

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
「会議を開く」などの意味で用いることはできない。Since it is a transitive verb, it is inadequate to use námúḷ to describe, for example,  the flower bloom.
「塞がっていたものに孔ができて通れるようになる」が中心語義なので、扉や窓、傷口などに用いるのが第一義であり、覆いが取れて中にアクセスできるようになるということから「包み紙を開く」「本を開く」などにも用いることができる。

translations.title: stative verb
forms: for [nominative] to be able to do [accusative/infinitive+ema]
for [nominative] to be capable of doing [infinitive+ema]
for [nominative] to have the ability to do [infinitive+ema]
for [nominative] to be able to perform [accusative/infinitive+ema]

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Unlike cognates in 牌 or 藍, it does not have the nuance of resisting / giving a counterblow. For those meanings, use naunijúḷ.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Denotes not "digit (characters used to describe numbers)" but "number (an abstract concept which is frequently represented using digits)". "Digit" is denoted by "bhájabáni".

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Denotes not "number (an abstract concept which is frequently represented using digits)" but "digit (characters used to describe numbers)". "Number" is denoted by "bágha".

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
Attaches to the root of an intransitive verb and creates a causative, transitive verb.
Example: cákíkúḷ "to come, to visit" → cákíkaúḷ "to make [accusative] visit, to bring about [accusative]"

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
Attaches to the root of an intransitive verb and creates a causative, transitive verb.
Example: janúḷ "to arise, to become generated" → janáúḷ "to make/create [accusative] out of [oṣa]"

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Joke word, coined as the calque of "poisson d'avril".

contents.text: "nautu" means "word"; "zepha" denotes "language", composed of many "nautu" and grammar. "bhátán zepha" is "bhátán language"; "bhátán nautu" is "bhátán words".

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Unlike in 牌, this phrase is not used for calling/addressing to someone, but used exclusively for greeting.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: バート語の文法上はsentence-final particleとして扱うが、実際にtの音で発音されるわけではなく、あくまで感嘆を表すための記号である。故に、ラテン字転写では感嘆符で転写するが、バート文字で書く場合には、単語tを書きその後ろにピリオドを打つ必要がある。

contents.title: usage
contents.text: the plural form of the consonant-stem noun k. Since this is extremely confusing, I added this as an entry of this dictionary.

translations.title: consonant-stem noun
forms: the phrase used to denote the phrase "ká" to mean the plural of "k"

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Since the phrase "ká" can either be the third person feminine singular pronoun or the plural of "k" (thing), this phrase can be used to disambiguate them.

translations.title: vowel-stem noun
forms: the phrase used to denote the phrase "ká" to mean the third person feminine singular pronoun

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Since the phrase "ká" can either be the third person feminine singular pronoun or the plural of "k" (thing), this phrase can be used to disambiguate them.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text:
The noun phrase "all time" is to be spelled with two words, that is, as "bhá káṇa"。
While the noun "bhákáṇa" can only be used in the genitive case, "káṇám" can be used in all cases. Also, while "káṇám"はどちらかというと未来に無限に続くことを意図するのに対し、bhákáṇaは単に「常である」様を表す。

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: While káṇám implies the notion of infinite eternity, bhákáṇa simply signifies that something always holds.

contents.title: etymological information
contents.text: eはアイル語reae、パイグ語la1などと同根であるが、現在では単独では死語である。ただし、nautuhomá eの構成要素としては残っており、またaṭam_kádなどと異なり文法上の制約には反していないことから、この連語自体をnautuhomá eでくっつけてnautuhomá_eと書くことはない。

contents.title: etymological information
contents.text: The general term for the dialects in which the distinction between bh and w is not maintained. Many of such dialects lack the aspirates; the aspirates in the standard language have become fricatives, approximants, and so on.

contents.title: etymological information
contents.text: The general term for the dialects in which the distinction between bh and w is not maintained. Many of such dialects lack the aspirates; the aspirates in the standard language have become fricatives, approximants, and so on.

forms: for [nominative] to be a replacement of [accusative]

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Attaches to the root of both an intransitive verb and a transitive verb and creates a causative verb. If the original verb is intransitive, the agent (causee) is marked in the accusative case; if the original verb is transitive, the original object remains in the accusative case and the agent (causee) is marked in the instrumental.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Attaches to the root of both an intransitive verb and a transitive verb and creates a causative verb. If the original verb is intransitive, the agent (causee) is marked in the accusative case; if the original verb is transitive, the original object remains in the accusative case and the agent (causee) is marked in the instrumental.

contents.title: etymological information
contents.text: 牌 hia1 + 牌 aik2 + 牌 a。パイグ語 aik2 と異なり、バート語kádには「光」の他にもkádúḷ「目立つ」の名詞化として「視線・注目」という意味がある。また、バート語では、「属格 + k」の主格が単体の属格で現れるため、属格接辞が結果として単立できるが、パイグ語ではこれは不可能であり、この位置のaは感嘆詞として解釈される。よってパイグ語 hia1 aik2 a. は「光りたいです。」という意味にしかならない、言うなれば「伐製牌語」である。hi- が x- で借用されているのは、ワート弁の影響である。

contents.title: culture
contents.text: 「大移住」。「大退去」とも。バート人がグォン・アルト藩国を去らなくてはいけなくなった2000年の痛ましい事件とそれに次ぐ混乱を指す。単に「行く」の意味もあれば「(永久に)去る」の意味を持つbohúḷは（訳語が揺れるのはそのため）、心の故郷であるグォン・アルト藩国に帰れる見込みの乏しいバート人の思いをよく表現しているともいえよう。

contents.title: usage
contents.text: the contraction of the dependent noun "k" followed by the copula "hem".

contents.title: usage
contents.text: As a result of semantic widening, the word "elameniác" not only includes the members of the working class but can also include entrepreneurs, CEOs or owners of a company, unlike the original word "elmen'iars".

contents.title: culture
contents.text: Fire is traditionally considered to be a collection of kádakáná.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text:
bhá + noun :  "all (noun)" (e.g. bhá ákíjami hína: "every day (someone does something)")
		-> for any ákíjam, the statement holds

genitive + nau : "all of (noun), the entirety of (noun)" (e.g. ákíjamán nauḍi hína: "all day long" )
		-> for any part of an ákíjam, the statement holds

bhá + genitive + nau : "the entirety of all (noun)" (e.g. bhá ákíjamán nauḍi hína: "24/7")
		-> the combination of the two above

contents.text: If whatever is in the instrumental case is a human or an animal, "behind" is defined in the human's or the animal's point of view. Otherwise, "behind" is defined by either the speaker's or the listener's point of view.

contents.title: culture
contents.text: Traditionally treated as what lies at the "life" side of the boundary between "life" and "non-life". Hence it is also a metaphor of procreation and sexual reproduction.

forms: adversative; denotes that an action is unpleasant or undesirable

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
Mainly used in:
* first person passive "I am annoyed that he/she/it/they did this to me"
* second person passive "how dare he/she/it/they did this to you"
* third person active "how dare he/she/it/they did this"
* third person passive "how dare he/she/it/they did this to him/her/it/them"

contents.title: usage
contents.text: 人名。バート人名はもともと「父名 ghátu 名前」が基礎的な形で、姓というシステムが本来的に用いられなかったため、後世外来姓と対比する形でbhátnímaṣが付けられた。位置的にはヴェフィスやリナエストの名前形式に準ずる位置であり、バート人が王朝時代からリナエスト藩国と接していたことを考えると後世に他民族語のそれに合わせるために付与されたものであると考えられる。

contents.title: etymological information
contents.text: 本来的にはラーヴァヌーは言語名であり民族名はドゥバーギョであるが、リパライン語の影響もありḍubájonímaṣではなくgháwanúnímaṣが定着している。

contents.title: culture
contents.text:
Stir-fry some meat and some vegetables with some oil, farmad seeds, ketysn, dītijysn, a variety of spices (such as suluj, alasakirfinaz, finorxonas) and some cooking wine. Then add some water, some xōla and some mushroom and then simmer. Add as much salt, fish sauce and cooked rice as you think makes it taste right.
While its name in Linepāine is derived from "bhátán rásit", it is not considered as belonging to their culture by the bhátán population, and hence its name in bhátán is the contraction of "la phertarrarsiten-curibajmorbern".

contents.text: Because this word is used in the colloquial register, an infinitive is usually not followed by "ema" even when used in place of an accusative.

contents.text: Used when it is not guaranteed that the listener is hearing what the speaker is saying.

contents.text: "páwa" is used more frequently than "pháwa". "ṣiṇṇa" is more formal, while "páwa" and "pháwa" are quite colloquial.

contents.text: "páwa" is used more frequently than "pháwa". "ṣiṇṇa" is more formal, while "páwa" and "pháwa" are quite colloquial.

contents.text: The term "gháwanúnímaṣ" is much more commonly used than "ḍubájonímaṣ"

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Used instead of hína hemakátá "to be in" when the noun that follows is an action. Note that, since there are four consecutive long vowel, the antepenultimate gets shortened without a dhez.

contents.title: difference between synonyms
contents.text: Since horabát is derived from the word hor- "to write down," some people use horabát only for cultures that have been handed down in written form, and epa_híja for others. However, it is common to use horabát regardless of whether it is written down or not, and using the word "epa_híja" gives the impression of a translated document.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: must be followed by a noun

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Expresses a clear denial, contempt, disrespect, or disparagement of the previous statement made by the other person. It is usually read in a descending tone, but can be read in an ascending tone to make it a little less rude.

contents.title: culture
contents.text: The religiously significant sentence in Linepāine "ban missen tonir l'es birleen alefis io" which means "Pertaining to our God of grace, Alefis", written at the beginning of a chapter in the Epic of Skyliorti'e.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: Can include a country with a constitutional monarchy if the power of the monarch is severly limited.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: The meaning of "bhodibhattá" is often explained as "fish seasoning or salt", but this is a remnant of the fact that many bhátán people lived in the inland areas in the days when refrigeration and transportation technologies were lacking. In modern times, the word is also often used to describe the flavor of seafood.

contents.title: cognate(s)
contents.text: A version of the so-called bhátán mushroom soup (see "phecú") with noodles added instead of rice.

contents.title: usage
contents.text:
to say "somewhere above A", you use A's instrumental case followed by ṣá.
kaṭádhabhau ṣaghi hína kí hemabáta hem. "There was a man above a ship."

contents.text: This phrase is used to describe leaving the speaker's current position and returning to somewhere else.

contents.title: culture
contents.text: 長さとピッチによって定まる韻律を持つ、韻律定型詩の一種。「低長 +	(高短) + 低長 + 高」→「低長 +	(高短) + 低長 + 高」→「低長 + 高 + 低 + 低 + 高、または、低長+ 低長 + 低 + 高」の形を持つ行から構成される。

contents.text: It is used primarily in the form káṇabhodiḍi ghi josedúḷ (literal translation: to sink in the sea of time), meaning "lost to history; the record is lost, and is perhaps forever unknowable."

contents.title: etymological information
contents.text: Since the vowel correspondence is irregular, it is possible that this word is an early loanword from a language which used [ə] for this word.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: When using verbs that express emotion, it is natural to use this adverb when the speaker is different the subject of the emotion. In particular, the presence or absence of dhama contributes considerably to the determination of the most natural interpretation, especially when no information about the subject of feeling emotion can be inferred from verb conjugation. However, since this adverb is placed based on the fact that the feelings of others are ultimately unknowable and can only be inferred, dhama should *not* be placed if the storytelling uses the third person omniscient point of view.

contents.title: culture
contents.text: The word has two meanings: "a mythical being whose face is a dog and the rest is a man" and "a clown who wears a dog mask and fools around at festivals".

contents.title: usage
contents.text: An adverb placed at the beginning of an inserted phrase to indicate a contrasting idea. Always used in pair with the adverb "ja". Very archaic.

contents.title: usage
contents.text: An adverb placed right before the verb that terminates the inserted phrase.  Always used in pair with the adverb "ja". Very archaic.
